content: quote: Originally posted by klassylady25: Once you hand the enemy the plans for the battle, the battle is over. Raise the white flag of surrender. See article here: 'http://www.rferl.org/content/The_End_Of_The_US_War_On_Terror/1609936.html' Written April 16, 2009 Radio Free Europe "Do you remember where you were the day the "global war on terror" ended? Like most people, you probably didn't even notice that it had. And that may be because the "war" didn't end the way the man who started it -- former U.S. President George W. Bush -- often predicted it would: with "complete victory" in the "great struggle between the forces of freedom and the forces of terror." It ended with an e-mail, sent under a new administration led by President Barack Obama. Sometime during the week of March 25, the government agency that reviews the public statements of administration officials before they're disseminated sent an e-mail to employees of the U.S. Defense Department. The e-mail read: "This administration prefers to avoid using the term 'long war' or 'global war on terror.' Please use 'Overseas Contingency Operation.'" Once you hand the enemy the plans for the battle, the battle is over. Raise the white flag of surrender. We never had a plan to hand over thats was the problem and is why were still there. The B&G bumbler even declared mission accomplished when it didnt even begin. Then it was hearts and minds,No exit stategy, ROEs that worked against the troops, and now the surge.

content: quote: Originally posted by scooter_mech: The CIA reports? National security took a big hit... How so? Before we can regain the trust and respect of the rest of the world, we have to admit that the last administration was not working in the best interests of America or the rest of the world, or complying with our laws and international laws, but acting in his own self-interests and pressing his myopic agenda. We must clean house inside and out, and that includes airing our dirty laundry. All if this would not have been necessary if the last administration had shown the proper respect and stood up for our Constitution and legally enacted and ratified international treaties. Instead he acted like a Third-World despot and called himself the, "Decider," and tossed out or just ignored any law that stood in his way...including our Constitution and the Geneva Convention. He and his henchmen are lucky that they are not being charged and tried as traitors.

content: The "official" talking point from the past administration and their supporters, apparently is that Obama has now tied the hands of not only himself, but future President's as well. Let's hope so! Let's pray our nation never goes down that rabbit hole again. And, let's pressure the White House to pardon those little people who are in jail now, the Privates and Sergeants who are serving time for the same crimes for which their masters will not be held accountable. If those who ordered it can escape prosecution, it's dishonorable and unfair to continue punishing the underlings who carried out the policy. All are equally guilty, so the punishment, or lack thereof, should be equal too. What's most striking about it is just what Andrew Sullivan points out in his article in the current edtion of The Atlantic and what someone once referred to as the "banality of evil" in relation to Nazi Germany. The people who authorized, and conducted, these things are not bad people, nor are they recognizable monsters. They are just like you and I and could be standing behind you in line at the store and you'd never notice them. I always warned my kids and grandkids that child molesters do not come with a giant neon sign on their head which says, "Warning!" Neither do psychotics and the players in this little drama bear witness to that fact. Mukasey, McMullen, Bush, Cheney, Yoo, Bybee, Gonzales. Look at them. What do you see? Pleasant looking men, friendly neighbors whom you'd invite over for a beer. They're not jack-booted thugs wielding a cat o' nine tails, but nondescript, regular Joe's, the kind of people you want to trust. But, they aren't trustworthy. They are monsters, though they'll never see, nor understand their own culpability. Like the Nazi's who went to the gallows convinced of their own innocence, they're bewildered by the outrage directed against them and will die without ever comprehending what they've done. If nothing else good comes from all this, I hope we American's finally recognize that we are no different than anyone else, that the moral superiority we think we have is a chimera, a lie we've told ourselves to shield us from the truth of our own evil. The dark impulses which drove the Nazi's or Pol Pot or Joe Stalin exists within our own breasts too. Our hearts are as black as the most heinous criminals in history and it only requires the right set of circumstances to reveal it. However, I'm not optimistic in that regard. We, as a people, have been guilty of far worse in our history, yet still don't recognize the truth, so why should we this time? If we can still excuse Wounded Knee or McCarthyism; if we can still justify separate but equal and apply it not to blacks, but to homosexuals; if we accept the term "collateral damage" without blinking, why would these revelations about torturing in the name of The People cause us to look inward and see our own guilt? After all, it was once again someone else who did it, not us. But, it WAS us and is STILL us. If our whole people can take the credit when things go right, why shouldn't we all bear the guilt when things go wrong? If WE won WWII, didn't WE also aid and abet the torturing of our enemies today? Of course we did but, like those who authorized it, we'll never see our own guilt because we're not....like them. But, we are.

If nothing else good comes from all this, I hope we American's finally recognize that we are no different than anyone else, that the moral superiority we think we have is a chimera, a lie we've told ourselves to shield us from the truth of our own evil. The dark impulses which drove the Nazi's or Pol Pot or Joe Stalin exists within our own breasts too. Our hearts are as black as the most heinous criminals in history and it only requires the right set of circumstances to reveal it. However, I'm not optimistic in that regard. We, as a people, have been guilty of far worse in our history, yet still don't recognize the truth, so why should we this time? If we can still excuse Wounded Knee or McCarthyism; if we can still justify separate but equal and apply it not to blacks, but to homosexuals; if we accept the term "collateral damage" without blinking, why would these revelations about torturing in the name of The People cause us to look inward and see our own guilt? After all, it was once again someone else who did it, not us. But, it WAS us and is STILL us. If our whole people can take the credit when things go right, why shouldn't we all bear the guilt when things go wrong? If WE won WWII, didn't WE also aid and abet the torturing of our enemies today? Of course we did but, like those who authorized it, we'll never see our own guilt because we're not....like them. But, we are.

content: quote: Originally posted by klassylady25: Once you hand the enemy the plans for the battle, the battle is over. Raise the white flag of surrender. See article here: 'http://www.rferl.org/content/The_End_Of_The_US_War_On_Terror/1609936.html' Written April 16, 2009 Radio Free Europe "Do you remember where you were the day the "global war on terror" ended? Like most people, you probably didn't even notice that it had. And that may be because the "war" didn't end the way the man who started it -- former U.S. President George W. Bush -- often predicted it would: with "complete victory" in the "great struggle between the forces of freedom and the forces of terror." It ended with an e-mail, sent under a new administration led by President Barack Obama. Sometime during the week of March 25, the government agency that reviews the public statements of administration officials before they're disseminated sent an e-mail to employees of the U.S. Defense Department. The e-mail read: "This administration prefers to avoid using the term 'long war' or 'global war on terror.' Please use 'Overseas Contingency Operation.'" What's most striking about it is just what Andrew Sullivan points out in his article in the current edtion of The Atlantic and what someone once referred to as the "banality of evil" in relation to Nazi Germany. The people who authorized, and conducted, these things are not bad people, nor are they recognizable monsters. They are just like you and I and could be standing behind you in line at the store and you'd never notice them. I always warned my kids and grandkids that child molesters do not come with a giant neon sign on their head which says, "Warning!" Neither do psychotics and the players in this little drama bear witness to that fact. Mukasey, McMullen, Bush, Cheney, Yoo, Bybee, Gonzales. Look at them. What do you see? Pleasant looking men, friendly neighbors whom you'd invite over for a beer. They're not jack-booted thugs wielding a cat o' nine tails, but nondescript, regular Joe's, the kind of people you want to trust. But, they aren't trustworthy. They are monsters, though they'll never see, nor understand their own culpability. Like the Nazi's who went to the gallows convinced of their own innocence, they're bewildered by the outrage directed against them and will die without ever comprehending what they've done. If nothing else good comes from all this, I hope we American's finally recognize that we are no different than anyone else, that the moral superiority we think we have is a chimera, a lie we've told ourselves to shield us from the truth of our own evil. The dark impulses which drove the Nazi's or Pol Pot or Joe Stalin exists within our own breasts too. Our hearts are as black as the most heinous criminals in history and it only requires the right set of circumstances to reveal it. However, I'm not optimistic in that regard. We, as a people, have been guilty of far worse in our history, yet still don't recognize the truth, so why should we this time? If we can still excuse Wounded Knee or McCarthyism; if we can still justify separate but equal and apply it not to blacks, but to homosexuals; if we accept the term "collateral damage" without blinking, why would these revelations about torturing in the name of The People cause us to look inward and see our own guilt? After all, it was once again someone else who did it, not us. But, it WAS us and is STILL us. If our whole people can take the credit when things go right, why shouldn't we all bear the guilt when things go wrong? If WE won WWII, didn't WE also aid and abet the torturing of our enemies today? Of course we did but, like those who authorized it, we'll never see our own guilt because we're not....like them. But, we are.

content: quote: Originally posted by klassylady25: Once you hand the enemy the plans for the battle, the battle is over. Raise the white flag of surrender. See article here: 'http://www.rferl.org/content/The_End_Of_The_US_War_On_Terror/1609936.html' Written April 16, 2009 Radio Free Europe "Do you remember where you were the day the "global war on terror" ended? Like most people, you probably didn't even notice that it had. And that may be because the "war" didn't end the way the man who started it -- former U.S. President George W. Bush -- often predicted it would: with "complete victory" in the "great struggle between the forces of freedom and the forces of terror." It ended with an e-mail, sent under a new administration led by President Barack Obama. Sometime during the week of March 25, the government agency that reviews the public statements of administration officials before they're disseminated sent an e-mail to employees of the U.S. Defense Department. The e-mail read: "This administration prefers to avoid using the term 'long war' or 'global war on terror.' Please use 'Overseas Contingency Operation.'" Once you hand the enemy the plans for the battle, the battle is over. Raise the white flag of surrender. We never had a plan to hand over thats was the problem and is why were still there. The B&G bumbler even declared mission accomplished when it didnt even begin. Then it was hearts and minds,No exit stategy, ROEs that worked against the troops, and now the surge.

content: The "official" talking point from the past administration and their supporters, apparently is that Obama has now tied the hands of not only himself, but future President's as well. Let's hope so! Let's pray our nation never goes down that rabbit hole again. And, let's pressure the White House to pardon those little people who are in jail now, the Privates and Sergeants who are serving time for the same crimes for which their masters will not be held accountable. If those who ordered it can escape prosecution, it's dishonorable and unfair to continue punishing the underlings who carried out the policy. All are equally guilty, so the punishment, or lack thereof, should be equal too. What's most striking about it is just what Andrew Sullivan points out in his article in the current edtion of The Atlantic and what someone once referred to as the "banality of evil" in relation to Nazi Germany. The people who authorized, and conducted, these things are not bad people, nor are they recognizable monsters. They are just like you and I and could be standing behind you in line at the store and you'd never notice them. I always warned my kids and grandkids that child molesters do not come with a giant neon sign on their head which says, "Warning!" Neither do psychotics and the players in this little drama bear witness to that fact. Mukasey, McMullen, Bush, Cheney, Yoo, Bybee, Gonzales. Look at them. What do you see? Pleasant looking men, friendly neighbors whom you'd invite over for a beer. They're not jack-booted thugs wielding a cat o' nine tails, but nondescript, regular Joe's, the kind of people you want to trust. But, they aren't trustworthy. They are monsters, though they'll never see, nor understand their own culpability. Like the Nazi's who went to the gallows convinced of their own innocence, they're bewildered by the outrage directed against them and will die without ever comprehending what they've done. If nothing else good comes from all this, I hope we American's finally recognize that we are no different than anyone else, that the moral superiority we think we have is a chimera, a lie we've told ourselves to shield us from the truth of our own evil. The dark impulses which drove the Nazi's or Pol Pot or Joe Stalin exists within our own breasts too. Our hearts are as black as the most heinous criminals in history and it only requires the right set of circumstances to reveal it. However, I'm not optimistic in that regard. We, as a people, have been guilty of far worse in our history, yet still don't recognize the truth, so why should we this time? If we can still excuse Wounded Knee or McCarthyism; if we can still justify separate but equal and apply it not to blacks, but to homosexuals; if we accept the term "collateral damage" without blinking, why would these revelations about torturing in the name of The People cause us to look inward and see our own guilt? After all, it was once again someone else who did it, not us. But, it WAS us and is STILL us. If our whole people can take the credit when things go right, why shouldn't we all bear the guilt when things go wrong? If WE won WWII, didn't WE also aid and abet the torturing of our enemies today? Of course we did but, like those who authorized it, we'll never see our own guilt because we're not....like them. But, we are.
